reviewText: The following is a guide from the International Movie Data Base.  As you can readily see, the ratings go down for each sequel.  I found that I had to agree as I watched them in one marathon.The Matrix - IMDB rating = 8.7.  Thomas A. Anderson is a man living two lives. By day he is an average computer programmer and by night a hacker known as Neo. Neo has always questioned his reality, but the truth is far beyond his imagination. Neo finds himself targeted by the police when he is contacted by Morpheus, a legendary computer hacker branded a terrorist by the government. Morpheus awakens Neo to the real world, a ravaged wasteland where most of humanity have been captured by a race of machines that live off of the humans' body heat and electrochemical energy and who imprison their minds within an artificial reality known as the Matrix. As a rebel against the machines, Neo must return to the Matrix and confront the agents: super-powerful computer programs devoted to snuffing out Neo and the entire human rebellionThe Matrix Reloaded - IMDB rating = 7.1.  6 months after the events depicted in The Matrix, Neo has proved to be a good omen for the free humans, as more and more humans are being freed from the matrix and brought to Zion, the one and only stronghold of the Resistance. Neo himself has discovered his superpowers including super speed, ability to see the codes of the things inside the matrix and a certain degree of pre-cognition. But a nasty piece of news hits the human resistance: 250,000 machine sentinels are digging to Zion and would reach them in 72 hours. As Zion prepares for the ultimate war, Neo, Morpheus and Trinity are advised by the Oracle to find the Keymaker who would help them reach the Source. Meanwhile Neo's recurrent dreams depicting Trinity's death have got him worried and as if it was not enough, Agent Smith has somehow escaped deletion, has become more powerful than before and has fixed Neo as his next targetThe Matrix Revolutions - IMDB rating = 6.6. reviewText: The matrix has been around long enough now that pretty much everyone knows the story.  A war between humans and machines, humans lost and were used as batteries to power the machines.  A few formed a resistance and continued the war in almost covert fashion (or so we are lead to think).The first movie was truly ground breaking, both in story (lets face it, it was one of the few original movies of its time that was not a reboot or sequel) and in terms of special effects.  The whole "bullet time" concept that they used to give characters powers in the Matrix was like nothing that we had seen up to that point.  Yes CGI and digital effects have evolved in a huge way since then but the original film was really the bridge between what was being done in films like Blade to what you got in the  Harry Potter films, the Lord of the Rings movies and almost every sci-fi/fantasy movie out now.Most of the criticism of the movies themselves tend to center around the continuation of the story in Reloaded and Revolutions.  Although given that the anticipation for the Matrix sequels rivaled that for the Star Wars Prequels (which also came out at the same time) given the popularity of the original film I honestly don't know what story they could have told that would satisfy everybody.  In some ways I do think the film makers had the Lucas complex of falling too much in love with the CGI, especially since at that point they did not have the technology to make the digital characters look as real as Gollum in LOTR, so during the burly brawl in Reloaded when they switch from the actors to all digital it looks like a video game.  I personally however think the story continuation that was done in the 2nd and 3rd films is better upon repeated viewings than when I originally saw them in the theater.What makes the set shine however is the tons of bonus material.  For each 2 hr movie, you get anywhere from 3-4 hrs of bonus content per disc.  Multiple commentaries on the movie, several making of and behind the scenes features for each movie.  A lot of explanation of the digital effects and why they did things the way they did.  A great look at the stunts and the trainings that all the actors did to do as much of the fight sequences and wire work as they could.  Say what you want about Keanu Reeves acting ability, but he busted his ass when it came to training to do the fight sequences which were of course the staple of his character.Aside from the bonus material on each movie disc, you get all the Animatrix features that fleshed out the story (both before the original movie showing how the war started) and in between the films where we got bits and pieces of information but not the entire story.  Plus you get a bunch of bonus material on how the animatrix stories were made.  Finally there are 2 discs that revolve more around the story itself, how the filmmakers came up with the story, and some of the early concept art, as well as the featuretts from the video game.  So if you are one who loves going through the bonus material on the discs then you will be extremely happy with all you get, because you can spend hours upon hours with all that is there.The A/V quality of the movies on blu ray is very good.  There are some limitations because of the fact that the movies are older now (with the first movie being about 15 years old), but they are better on blu ray than the original DVD releases.  I would say that this set really is for hardcore fans of the series overall.  If you hated the second and third movies as some do, then you are far better off getting the stand alone Matrix blu ray and being done with that.  Because that is only a small part of what you will get in this set.  If you like the other movies but do not really care about going through all the bonus material then you probably just want to stick with the movie trilogy.  Bit if you want to get the entire experience, then you cannot go wrong with what is here.
summary: Everything Matrix related in one spot

reviewText: With the horde of DVD double dipping of late, it was pretty much a forgone conclusion that some kind of deluxe package for the Matrix trilogy would be made, especially considering the extras on the single disc edition of the first film and the fluff filled extras of the two disc sequels. Instead, there are commentary tracks by philosophers (read, hardcore fans making the Matrix into metaphysics) and critics alike.  This is a smart move on the part of the brothers, but just about anyone else knows that the two are too busy counting their money to care.  That aside, if you are one of the very few who don't own any of the film's on DVD and are a Matrix fan, then this is worth picking up, but for others, just like the theme of the films, the choice is entirely up to you.

Frankly - to date the Matrix Trilogy is hands down THE BEST implementation of a movie using the HD-DVD format in my opinion.  From the miniature overlay in the bottom corner of the making of WHILE YOU ARE WATCHING THE SCENES THEMSELVES IN THE MOVIE, to the amount of extras (not on extra discs thank you) they really took their time.  The Video quality is noticeably sharper and cleaner than the DVD version.  As a comparison - I have the Ultimate Neo Collection that comes with the Neo Bust and the 10-disc DVD Collection.  This 4-DVD set has all the same material in a much more organized and easily viewable format and it is much easier to find and use the information.  Even a casual viewer has to give credit to the ability to see the special effects in a mini-window during the movie - easily shut off is they do not want it.Overall if you are a fan of the Matrix seris this is  a no-brainer of a purchase.  If not then I don't know what to tell you other than this might be worth the money just to be able to show-off what HD-DVD can do other than be more expensive than the original DVD sets of these movies.

I'm glad they made me buy the sequels again, because it allowed me to watch the movies again with a fresh perspective. Each disc is dual-sided, with the contents of each side being a bit-for-bit copy (a "disc image") of a previous DVD release.  Usually the very first DVD release of a film is used as the master for each side, which could be either single-layer or dual-layer.  If the DVD master that is used first came out at the infancy of DVD production (the late 1990s), there may be little to no extras, and even a poor film transfer when compared to a later re-release.  Also, if that original release was a two-disc set, or a dual-sided disc (see: Lethal Weapon 4), only Disc 1 or Side A will be used.  The "4 Film Favorites" line is priced with the budget-conscience consumer in mind, with Target having the lowest price at 9.99 each (occasionally on sale for 8.99). reviewText: How long I have waited for film such as the matrix films, but I never thought that the films would take on quite so many philosophical/social/psychological/mythical/religious positions into three films and to have done it so magnificently! I still marvel that the films got made at all! But, the commentaries were highly helpful especially from the brilliant philosophers Dr. Cornell West and Ken Wilbur. Their interpretation of the films was more than I had hoped for, very insightful and enlightening; my only wish would be that they should have been given a dvd unto themselves to discuss The Matrix films! However, the critics, apart from their comments on style and camera work, I found simply humorous. I mean these guys were just clueless. The basic concepts which they should have understood in the first films they were still wondering about in the third. But even though the critics were clearly not up to the intellectual challenge of the films (as I suppose is always the case when artists are more intelligent than their critics)their comments about film, in general, were entertaining. But I did feel listening to the critics that The matrix films have become, to the critics, simply films to jeer at because they simply do not understand it. And that is unfortunate because the Matrix films are not only propelled by camera work, music, action, etc. but by the ideas that the films present, and if you cannot understand the ideas then you are missing out on the very driving force that moves the plot forward. Overall, the presentaion of the dvd collection is great. I would definately reccomend it to all the hardcore fans (and you know who you are). The Matrix trilogy is simply a work of art and even the Star Wars/Lord of the Rings films cannot compare to it intellectually. The Matrix has mangaed to show in narrative the very paths that humanity must follow or make if they want to survive the next couple of thousand of years. It is the bold blueprint of tomorrow, and of course it is complex as the truth always is. As long as their are mindful people of high capacity there will always be the matrix films there for others to enjoy and learn from.

reviewText: The first Matrix film is a must own title. And if you must own it, go for this set, since it contains the DEFINATIVE version of the DVD. The superior remastered picture quality on disc 1 will be enough to get me to buy this massive set.As a series, the Matrix has kind of weak legs. The sequels offer some truly amazing images and action sequences, but the story is no-where near as good as the first one, and the overall quality is alot lower, production values aside. The big reason for this would be the fact that the first movie was an un-authorized adaptation of a story called "The Third Eye", which the Wachowski Bros. stole from another writer, who is only just now finally recieving a financial settlement from Warner Bros. Even though they stole the story for the first film, it was still good. But the second two movies were pretty much them working by themselves, and it's not hard to tell once you watch them. It was very dissapointing to see the series take such a sharp turn from cinematic gold to sci-fi obscurity, but at least we got some great action scenes out of it, even if the stuff between is poorly thought out. And the series ends with more of a whimper than a bang. You'll be very dissapointed with the way the series wraps things up, I'm afraid.Still, I consider myself to be a moderate fan of the series. I can forgive things like obnoxiouse and distastful rave sequences and a 5 minute long sex scene with strands of drool that take up half the screen because there's some good to be found withing the latter two films. And maybe, just maybe you'll almost be able to make sense of the series with this boxed set, since it contains almost all the Matrix lore that's ever been put on film, including The Animatrix disc and all the live-action footage from the game Enter The Matrix. So while no movie can justify the requirement of knowledge outside the films to make sense (or even come close to making sense), at least you can get it all in one purchase, in one box on your DVD shelf. Think of it as a visual encyclopedia of the Matrix world. I only bought the DVD for the first movie, so this set should be satasfying, other than that the movies themselves aren't particularly (with the exception of the first one). It's still a dissapointing movie series, but it's one that you might find worth owning.

reviewText: Sure, I liked the Matrix as much as the next movie goer.  It was quite the trippy little dollop of cyber-punk when it was released to the cinemas of 1999.  It sure quite amused and entertained as we all breathlessly awaited the upcoming adventures of Jar Jar Binks and the menacing Phantom.  Still though lets be honest.  If Neo started out in Zion as a six year old and then was shocked to find out on his first day of Kindergarten that 99% of humanity was hooked into batteries for the machines and living in the virtual Matrix it really wouldn't have been so mind shocking now would it.  Half the story of the Matrix was in how they unfolded and revealed itself to us.So thus therefore that was what was wrong with the Matrix II and 3 installments.  No more mind-blowing stuff was left to be revealed after the one and only big reveal.  There's a reason we weren't sitting in theaters watching that little Joel Osment kid seeing more dead people in Seventh and Eighth Senses movies.Certainly though I kinda halfheartedly enjoyed Matrix II especially that rave sequence in the caves of Zion.  That has inspired a few debauchery nights for party guests at my humble abode on more than one occasion; but not more than 3.  Still though Matrix II was something we all put up with knowing it was treading water till we got to the grand climax of a finish awaiting us in Matrix 3.And about that.  So we find out in Matrix 3 that Neo is simply a really good video gamer but he is terrible at fighting in real life.  When I saw him get his butt whipped and blinded i felt cheated.  Then it hit me as the movie continued onward that this was the least surprising part of the whole trilogy.  Of course Neo couldn't fight.  He was a video gamer.  but still after 388 minutes of pure unrequited fantasy nonsense for the Siblings that are the Wachovskis to unleash that little bit of reality on us was quite the true mind blowing moment of the whole endeavor.Still though I went ahead and popped in the Animatrix disc.  I couldn't make heads nor tails of it.  But it all looked rather visually weirdly freaky in a pretty much but not always good sort of way.  But don't ask me to recount any of that discs plot points.  I had no illicits on hand to help me unspool and unbend those stories.Either way, the disc collection sure is cheap.  I remember when it came out on DVD so expensive upon it's release.
